C++ Programming Guide

C++ Programming Guide #

Introduction to C++ #

C++ is a powerful general-purpose programming language that extends C with object-oriented features. Itâ€™s widely used in game development, system programming, and performance-critical applications.

Core Features #

1. Classes and Objects #

// Class definition
class Person {
private:
    string name;
    int age;
    
public:
    // Constructor
    Person(string n, int a) : name(n), age(a) {}
    
    // Member functions
    void displayInfo() const {
        cout << "Name: " << name << ", Age: " << age << endl;
    }
    
    // Getter and setter
    int getAge() const { return age; }
    void setAge(int a) { age = a; }
};

// Using the class
Person person("Alice", 25);
person.displayInfo();

2. Templates #

// Function template
template<typename T>
T max(T a, T b) {
    return (a > b) ? a : b;
}

// Class template
template<typename T>
class Stack {
private:
    vector<T> elements;
    
public:
    void push(T const& elem) {
        elements.push_back(elem);
    }
    
    T pop() {
        T top = elements.back();
        elements.pop_back();
        return top;
    }
};

3. STL Containers #

#include <vector>
#include <map>
#include <string>

// Vector usage
vector<int> numbers = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
numbers.push_back(6);

// Map usage
map<string, int> ages;
ages["Alice"] = 25;
ages["Bob"] = 30;

// Range-based for loop
for (const auto& pair : ages) {
    cout << pair.first << ": " << pair.second << endl;
}

4. Smart Pointers #

#include <memory>

// Unique pointer
unique_ptr<Person> person1(new Person("Alice", 25));
person1->displayInfo();

// Shared pointer
shared_ptr<Person> person2 = make_shared<Person>("Bob", 30);
shared_ptr<Person> person3 = person2;  // Reference count = 2

Modern C++ Features (C++11 and beyond) #

1. Auto Type Inference #

auto number = 42;        // int
auto text = "Hello";     // const char*
auto pi = 3.14159;       // double

// With lambda expressions
auto lambda = [](int x) { return x * x; };

2. Lambda Expressions #

vector<int> numbers = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};

// Using lambda with algorithms
auto sum = accumulate(numbers.begin(), numbers.end(), 0,
    [](int total, int current) {
        return total + current;
    });

// Capturing variables
int multiplier = 10;
auto multiply = [multiplier](int x) { return x * multiplier; };

3. Move Semantics #

class Buffer {
private:
    int* data;
    size_t size;

public:
    // Move constructor
    Buffer(Buffer&& other) noexcept 
        : data(other.data), size(other.size) {
        other.data = nullptr;
        other.size = 0;
    }
    
    // Move assignment operator
    Buffer& operator=(Buffer&& other) noexcept {
        if (this != &other) {
            delete[] data;
            data = other.data;
            size = other.size;
            other.data = nullptr;
            other.size = 0;
        }
        return *this;
    }
};

Best Practices #

  1. Use RAII (Resource Acquisition Is Initialization)
  2. Prefer smart pointers over raw pointers
  3. Use const whenever possible
  4. Leverage STL algorithms and containers
  5. Follow the Rule of Five/Zero

Common Idioms #

1. RAII Pattern #

class FileHandler {
private:
    FILE* file;
    
public:
    FileHandler(const char* filename) {
        file = fopen(filename, "r");
    }
    
    ~FileHandler() {
        if (file) {
            fclose(file);
        }
    }
};

2. Pimpl Idiom #

// Header file
class Widget {
private:
    class Impl;
    unique_ptr<Impl> pimpl;
    
public:
    Widget();
    ~Widget();
    void doSomething();
};

// Implementation file
class Widget::Impl {
    // Implementation details
};

Exception Handling #

try {
    vector<int> vec;
    vec.at(5) = 10;  // Will throw out_of_range
} catch (const out_of_range& e) {
    cerr << "Out of range error: " << e.what() << endl;
} catch (...) {
    cerr << "Unknown error occurred" << endl;
}
